natural problem: Tony will paint 16 right, cylindrical columns. The top face and bottom face of each column will be covered, so those parts will  not be painted.  Each column is 18 feet tall and has a diameter  of 10 feet. One gallon of paint will cover 350 square feet. If paint is sold only in full gallons, how many gallons of paint must Tony buy to paint all 16 columns?
natural solution: Since each column has a radius of 5 feet and height of 18 feet, the lateral surface area of each column is $2 \pi (5) \cdot 18 = 180 \pi$ square feet.

Thus, the lateral surface area of 16 columns is $180\pi\cdot16\approx9043$ square feet. Since each gallon of paint covers 350 square feet, and since $9043/350\approx25.8$, we need $\boxed{26}$ gallons of paint.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes columns :: real and height diameter :: real and coverage :: real and gallons :: nat
assumes h0 : "columns = 16"
and h1 : "height = 18"
and h2 : "diameter = 10"
and h3 : "coverage = 350"
and h4 : "\<forall>gallons. gallons = (columns * (2 * pi * (diameter / 2) * height)) / coverage"
shows  "ceiling (gallons) = 26"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tony will paint 16 right, cylindrical columns. The top face and bottom face of each column will be covered, so those parts will  not be painted.  Each column is 18 feet tall and has a diameter  of 10 feet. One gallon of paint will cover 350 square feet. If paint is sold only in full gallons, how many gallons of paint must Tony buy to paint all 16 columns? The final Answer is 26
 ### Proof
 Since each column has a radius of 5 feet and height of 18 feet, the lateral surface area of each column is $2 \pi (5) \cdot 18 = 180 \pi$ square feet.
 Thus, the lateral surface area of 16 columns is $180\pi\cdot16\approx9043$ square feet. Since each gallon of paint covers 350 square feet, and since $9043/350\approx25.8$, we need $\boxed{26}$ gallons of paint.
 *)

theorem
fixes columns :: real and height diameter :: real and coverage :: real and gallons :: nat
assumes h0 : "columns = 16"
and h1 : "height = 18"
and h2 : "diameter = 10"
and h3 : "coverage = 350"
and h4 : "\<forall>gallons. gallons = (columns * (2 * pi * (diameter / 2) * height)) / coverage"
shows  "ceiling (gallons) = 26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Assume you have 16 columns, each with a height of 18 feet and a diameter of 10 feet. One gallon of paint covers 350 square feet. How many gallons of paint do you need to paint all the columns, if you can only purchase whole gallons of paint? The final answer is 26 gallons.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes columns :: nat and height diameter :: real
and square_feet_per_gallon :: real and gallons_needed :: nat
assumes h0 : "columns = 16"
and h1 : "height = 18"
and h2 : "diameter = 10"
and h3 : "square_feet_per_gallon = 350"
and h4 : "\<forall> columns. gallons_needed = \<lceil>((columns * height * diameter * pi) / square_feet_per_gallon)\<rceil>"
shows  "gallons_needed = 26"

 *)

fixes columns :: nat and height diameter :: real
and square_feet_per_gallon :: real and gallons_needed :: nat
assumes h0 : "columns = 16"

and h3 : "square_feet_per_gallon = 350"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes columns :: nat
and height diameter gallons_to_cover :: real
and surface_area_per_column total_surface_area total_gallons :: real
assumes h0 : "columns = 16"
and h1 : "height = 18"
and h2 : "diameter = 10"
and h3 : "gallons_to_cover = 350"
and h4 : "surface_area_per_column = pi * diameter * height"
and h5 : "total_surface_area = surface_area_per_column * columns"
and h6 : "total_gallons = ceil (total_surface_area / gallons_to_cover)"
shows  "total_gallons = 26"
